entry.title: @devnulling @gnuradio @GhostOP14 @Ghostop141 Yes, he did. But here I wanted to put something together quickly to postprocess some files. Mike's correlator runs in real time from network data.
entry.content: @devnulling @gnuradio @GhostOP14 @Ghostop141 Yes, he did. But here I wanted to put something together quickly to postprocess some files. Mike's correlator runs in real time from network data.

entry.title: @ka9q 8192 point. It's GNU Radio's FFT block, which uses fftw under the hood.
entry.content: @ka9q 8192 point. It's GNU Radio's FFT block, which uses fftw under the hood.

entry.title: Input throughput is ~124 MiB/s on a dual socket Xeon 4216, so I guess there's large room for improvement. I love the fact that we can put together an FX correlator flowgraph having 40 FFT blocks and 820 integrator blocks in just a couple dozen lines of code. (2/2)
entry.content: Input throughput is ~124 MiB/s on a dual socket Xeon 4216, so I guess there's large room for improvement. I love the fact that we can put together an FX correlator flowgraph having 40 FFT blocks and 820 integrator blocks in just a couple dozen lines of code. (2/2)

entry.title: Testing a @gnuradio software FX correlator for the ATA 20 antenna set up (40 inputs = 20 antennas x 2 polarizations). The deinterleave block that distributes the input turns out to be a huge bottleneck, but fortunately this doesn't need to run in real time. (1/2) pic.twitter.com/taNpQwVODs
entry.content: Testing a @gnuradio software FX correlator for the ATA 20 antenna set up (40 inputs = 20 antennas x 2 polarizations). The deinterleave block that distributes the input turns out to be a huge bottleneck, but fortunately this doesn't need to run in real time. (1/2) pic.twitter.com/taNpQwVODs

entry.title: @F4DAV @TM_Eubanks Shortly after launch was 7 hours this time, due to launch azimuth. By then it was pretty far. If we had it in view just as it launched, the problem would have been antenna pointing.
entry.content: @F4DAV @TM_Eubanks Shortly after launch was 7 hours this time, due to launch azimuth. By then it was pretty far. If we had it in view just as it launched, the problem would have been antenna pointing.

entry.title: @dh2va @nascom1 @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @coastal8049 @NASA_Orion @NASA @NASA_Gateway That's a great idea. I'm confident that requesting a very particular and isolated part of the system be transmitted unencrypted for outreach is more likely to be acknowledged than saying that in general they shouldn't use encryption.
entry.content: @dh2va @nascom1 @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @coastal8049 @NASA_Orion @NASA @NASA_Gateway That's a great idea. I'm confident that requesting a very particular and isolated part of the system be transmitted unencrypted for outreach is more likely to be acknowledged than saying that in general they shouldn't use encryption.

entry.title: The @IAU_CPS has released a statement on the worries of the astronomy community regarding the brightness & radio frequency usage of the @AST_SpaceMobile #BlueWalker3 satellite which deployed its 64 square meter antenna. It can outshine all but the 15th brightest stars in the sky.
entry.content: The @IAU_CPS has released a statement on the worries of the astronomy community regarding the brightness & radio frequency usage of the @AST_SpaceMobile #BlueWalker3 satellite which deployed its 64 square meter antenna. It can outshine all but the 15th brightest stars in the sky.

entry.title: @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 The 2 million km definition is CCSDS Category A, which includes the Lagrange points on purpose.
entry.content: @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 The 2 million km definition is CCSDS Category A, which includes the Lagrange points on purpose.

entry.title: @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 That's my impression as well, and it's the way that the CCSDS Green Book explains it. But I think there are also exceptions to that rule.
entry.content: @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 That's my impression as well, and it's the way that the CCSDS Green Book explains it. But I think there are also exceptions to that rule.

entry.title: @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 For Orion it's r=1/2 k=1024. I wouldn't say LDPC has displaced Turbo in deep space. Turbo k=1/6 is still the preferred coding. But LDPC is more common for near Earth, in which Orion fits better (near Earth is up to 2 million km).
entry.content: @ka9q @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 For Orion it's r=1/2 k=1024. I wouldn't say LDPC has displaced Turbo in deep space. Turbo k=1/6 is still the preferred coding. But LDPC is more common for near Earth, in which Orion fits better (near Earth is up to 2 million km).

entry.title: @ibelings @eb3frn That's very interesting. Keep us updated on your findings. I've never understood properly how all the ordinary vs extraordinary ionosphere polarization thing works. I was impressed by a talk in RSGB convention this year where they looked at polarization in 6m Es.
entry.content: @ibelings @eb3frn That's very interesting. Keep us updated on your findings. I've never understood properly how all the ordinary vs extraordinary ionosphere polarization thing works. I was impressed by a talk in RSGB convention this year where they looked at polarization in 6m Es.

entry.content: This. I imagine Luigi might have some particular case in mind with this criticism. I don't know the particular case, but I'm retweeting because this is broadly applicable and very well expressed. twitter.com/luigifcruz/sta…

entry.title: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 For DSN the go to reference is deepspace.jpl.nasa.gov/dsndocs/810-00… but it's a bit outdated. I noticed they list LDPC decoding as future capability, but they're using it currently for the Orion downlink.
entry.content: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 For DSN the go to reference is deepspace.jpl.nasa.gov/dsndocs/810-00… but it's a bit outdated. I noticed they list LDPC decoding as future capability, but they're using it currently for the Orion downlink.

entry.title: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 I'm not so familiar with those protocols, but I think they are for use with TDRS. I don't think the DSN can receive those on ground. This seems a good reference public.ccsds.org/Pubs/415x1b1.p…
entry.content: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 I'm not so familiar with those protocols, but I think they are for use with TDRS. I don't think the DSN can receive those on ground. This seems a good reference public.ccsds.org/Pubs/415x1b1.p…

entry.title: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 This brings the question: does the DSN have the capability to drive the PN ranging correlators using the carrier frequency estimate coming from an OQPSK demodulator, or does it need a residual carrier that a simple PLL can track?
entry.content: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 This brings the question: does the DSN have the capability to drive the PN ranging correlators using the carrier frequency estimate coming from an OQPSK demodulator, or does it need a residual carrier that a simple PLL can track?

entry.title: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 For simultaneous GMSK and PN ranging there is this CCSDS Green Book public.ccsds.org/Pubs/413x1g2.p… I haven't seen a document describing PN ranging on the Q component, while the I component is left for data.
entry.content: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 For simultaneous GMSK and PN ranging there is this CCSDS Green Book public.ccsds.org/Pubs/413x1g2.p… I haven't seen a document describing PN ranging on the Q component, while the I component is left for data.

entry.title: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 The switch is from 2 Msyms OQPSK for no ranging to residual carrier PM/PCM/NRZ 2 Msyms for ranging. I haven't looked into how they do ranging, but using a residual carrier mode would let them multiplex the data and ranging PN simply by addition.
entry.content: @IanJohnBuckley @nascom1 @coastal8049 The switch is from 2 Msyms OQPSK for no ranging to residual carrier PM/PCM/NRZ 2 Msyms for ranging. I haven't looked into how they do ranging, but using a residual carrier mode would let them multiplex the data and ranging PN simply by addition.

entry.title: @MaximusJackus @gnuradio Fair enough. entry.content: @MaximusJackus @gnuradio Fair enough. You'll have to believe me, look at the flowgraph in the post and see that it's an OQPSK demodulator (but still believe that the flowgraph corresponds to this screenshot), or download the IQ recording and check by yourself (and believe that the recording is not fake).
